Trump curbs enforcement of foreign antibribery law President Donald Trump directed the Justice Department on Monday to relax enforcement of a law used to prosecute U.S. companies who bribe foreign officials, saying it has put American business at a competitive disadvantage while operating abroad. In an executive order, the president instructed Attorney General Pam Bondi to pause actions taken under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act until the Justice Department can draft new guidance that “promotes American competitiveness and efficient use of federal law enforcement resources.” A fact sheet the White House distributed along with the order asserted that the law had long harmed U.S. companies through “overenforcement because they are prohibited from engaging in practices common among international competitors, creating an uneven playing field.” Enacted in 1977, the FCPA bars American businesses or their representatives from offering money or gifts to foreign officials to win business overseas. Since then, large corporations, including Lockheed Martin, Goldman Sachs, Haliburton, Chiquita, Goodyear and Daimler AG, have at points all run afoul of the statute, agreeing to multimillion-dollar settlement deals to resolve allegations that they’d provided illegal enticements to foreign leaders. Trump’s antipathy toward the FCPA predates his time in the White House. In a 2012 appearance on CNBC’s “Squawk Box,” he called the statute “ridiculous” and a “horrible law.” “Every other country in the world is doing it,” he said. “We’re not allowed to do so. It puts us at a huge disadvantage.” Trump publicly floated the idea of restricting enforcement during his first term but ultimately took no action. Even before his executive order Monday, Bondi had moved to narrow the Justice Department’s pursuit of foreign antibribery cases. Within hours of being sworn in as attorney general last week, she issued a directive instructing prosecutors to prioritize FCPA cases “related to foreign bribery that facilitates criminal operations of [drug and human smuggling] cartels” and “shift away from investigations that do not involve such a connection.”
